title: Day 1032
content:
# Day 1032

![[https://x.com/ScottAdamsSays/status/1880241008409211259](https://x.com/ScottAdamsSays/status/1880241008409211259)](https://miro.medium.com/1*HG5dVfiVAHCBrWN1lKx5Jg.png)

Good reminder to think twice about charts that give you sticker shock. Sure, it makes sense that in an online world, alcohol isn't as necessary as a social lubricant. But there are plenty of variables at play.

For one, inflation has squeezed Gen Z harder than past generations. The internet also changed things. Between memes, cat videos, and endless scrolling, it gave us both distraction and information. A lot of noise, but enough signal if you know where to listen. Health trends, wellness gurus, and that one friend who won't shut up about keto (_respect_) have all shaped how people think. The wise adapt. The stubborn double down.

So what is better competition or collaboration? 'Tis a good question. Most of the time, collaboration wins. But sometimes, competition is exactly what's needed. I wouldn't watch a football game if both teams were working together for a tie. That's not a game, that is a group project.

But when it comes to something like AI, I'd much rather see open-source innovation. Humanity building one of our most important technologies should be done together. Open. Transparent. Not controlled by a handful of big corporations. Not governed by politicians who barely understand it. And absolutely not in some unholy alliance between government and mega-corporations.

No...it should be driven forward by _**we the people**._ Built in the spirit of the MIT License. Free. Open. Unstoppable. Boom!

I like open source software that helps humanity. It's why I like Bitcoin and Nostr so much. Protocols for people instead of decrees disguised as laws (_aka_ protocols) imposed by people.

![Truth For The World](https://miro.medium.com/1*bGswPZQ_ixayebBCULN92Q.png)

See some signal below.

![Not bad](https://miro.medium.com/1*THRF4PUox9Y0SIIvlap1wA.png)

1/17/25

Conor Jay Chepenik
